Award.AwardTitle: MSB-ECA: A generalized framework for modeling the impacts of forest insects and pathogens in the Earth System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: MSB-ECA: A generalized framework for modeling the impacts of forest insects and pathogens in the Earth System

Forest insects and pathogens are global agents of ecosystem disturbance. In the United States, tree stress and mortality from insects and pathogens creates billions of dollars in costs for U.S. municipalities and individual property owners. The interactions between insects and pathogens and other disturbances, such as climate change, are highly uncertain, but in many cases climate change is expected to increase insect and pathogen activity. This project will develop a framework to simulate and forecast the impacts of forest insects and pathogens through a generalized method that accurately captures the large diversity of their impacts. This framework will be used to simulate the potential impacts of insect and pathogen outbreaks in forests across the continental U.S. and to investigate the specific impacts of two invasive insects ? gypsy moth and hemlock woolly adelgid ? in the eastern U.S. A key benefit of this research is that it will improve the ability to simulate future impacts of insects and pathogens on forests in combination with other disturbances like drought, heat waves, and extreme rainfall events. This research will also increase the diversity of the U.S. STEM workforce by training undergraduate women in cutting-edge quantitative methods.

Future feedbacks between forest insects and pathogens, forests, and climate change are not well understood at regional to continental spatial scales, due in part to the absence of the processes controlled by insects and pathogens within Earth System models. This research proposes a generalized framework in which impacts of insects and pathogens on plant physiology are scaled up to ecosystem-level processes that can be integrated into Earth System models. With this framework, this research tests three hypotheses regarding the response of forests to insects and pathogens: 1) at low intensities, insects and pathogens increase tree diversity, increase forest carbon storage, and increase water cycling, but at high intensities insects and pathogens create large-scale mortality; 2) the ability of insects and pathogens to impact a wide range of host species will be less likely to shift forest tree species composition but more likely to impact carbon and water cycling; 3) insects and pathogens that create a continuous stress, rather than periodic irruptions, are more likely to initiate impacts that are amplified by climate change. These hypotheses will be tested with theoretical modeling experiments across the continuous U.S. and with a second set of modeling experiments focused on two invasive insects in the eastern U.S.: 1) periodic irruption of the generalist, defoliating gypsy moth, and 2) slow and continuous stress from the species-specific, phloem-feeding hemlock woolly adelgid. Rather than modeling insects and pathogens as direct agents of mortality, this framework will more accurately simulate changes in individual host tree physiology and resulting changes in ecosystem processes. To facilitate the incorporation of this framework into other Earth System models, this research will develop two open-source training modules. The proposed research will also help to develop a diverse and competitive STEM workforce by training undergraduate women in research that uses advanced computational methods and develops skills in scientific communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insects and pathogens cause globally widespread disturbances to forests that can potentially cause amplifying feedbacks with climate change. Modeling and forecasting the impacts of insects and pathogens in forests is challenging due to the large diversity of different types of insects and pathogens. This project developed a data-model framework for simulating the impacts of insects and pathogens within an ecosystem model in a generalized framework that directly connects the impacts of insects and pathogens to plant physiology. The framework that was developed represents five main functional types of insects and pathogens that create impacts through changes in plant carbon pools. We used this framework to forecast the impacts and recovery from an unexpected outbreak of defoliating gypsy moth caterpillars in New England from 2015-2018 by merging satellite data, stream gage data, and forest plot data with a dynamic vegetation model. In this work we found threshold effects where forested areas defoliated in one or two consecutive years recovered baseline rates of ecosystem productivity within five years, but areas that were defoliated for three consecutive years experienced much higher rates of mortality and a persistent loss of productivity compared to a baseline scenario of no defoliation. We also found that defoliation was positively correlated to increased seasonal water yield at the watershed scale due to the loss of evapotranspiration flux with defoliation and that defoliation increased the magnitude of high and medium instantaneous streamflow events. Additional field and modeling work in this project found that areas with lower nitrogen content experienced greater defoliation intensity, providing helpful insight into future potential for forecasting the direct impacts of gypsy moth defoliation during irruption events. 

A second set of efforts in this project used the novel data-model framework to investigate the impacts of multiple different types of insects and pathogens in northeastern U.S. forests. We simulated the impacts of phloem-feeding hemlock woolly adelgid and xylem-disrupting emerald ash borer at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, a novel site for these insects. Our forecasts predicted that the hemlock woolly adelgid is likely to create larger and more persistent impacts due to the prolonged, multi-year stress effects of phloem feeding in conjunction with the aggregated spatial pattern of hemlock in the landscape. This is in contrast with the rapid mortality caused by the xylem disruption of the emerald ash borer and patchy distribution of ash in the landscape where surrounding trees can quickly compensate for lost productivity. This research provides a framework for merging datasets with models to consider realistic direct impacts of insects and pathogens in forests and also to simulate and better understand indirect secondary ecosystem impacts from these types of disturbances.

This work also developed a teaching module for an introductory biology, ecology, or environmental science course that uses examples of invasive insects in New England as a system for developing conceptual and computational models. This teaching module facilitates the development of skills at the intersection of data science and computational modeling for novice students that could be extended in future work.
